awd_titl_txt: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2019 International Symposium on Software Testing and Analysis (ISSTA 2019)
awd_abstract_narration:
The grant supports students to travel to the International Symposium on Software Testing and Analysis (ISSTA 2019), which is the top conference on software testing/analysis and one of the top conferences in the field of Software Engineering. This year the event will take place in Beijing, China in mid-July. The purpose is to facilitate technical exchange of information and research conversations/collaborations, as well as advances in the field made possible by these interactions. Mechanisms are specified to ensure participation of under-represented groups.

The benefits are the education, training and mentoring received by the participants. The international nature of this conference helps develop a globally-aware workforce of research and educators within the US and helps build the community of researchers in the field of Software Engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This grant help students to defray the costs of traveling to and attending the ACM SIGSOFT International Symposium on Software Testing and Analysis (ISSTA 2019) will be held in Beijing, China from July 15–19, 2019. ISSTA is the premier “specialist” research conference in software testing and analysis, complementary to wider “generalist” research conferences in the broader field of software engineering. Participation in ISSTA is an important step in the preparation of graduate students pursuing research in software testing and analysis. It is key to establishing a professional network, to building an appreciation of the norms of the research community, and to understanding the research problems and promising approaches at the frontier of the field. The funding enabled broader participation by students, especially by those that may not have adequate support at their educational institution. A concerted effort was made to expand participation in the area by reaching out to women, underrepresented minorities, and younger students new to the research area.

Testimonies from funded students demonstrate the benefits of the award. E.g.,:

"ISSTA 2019 was a fantastic experience for you me and it is wonderful that NSF was able to help fund my trip to the conference. Specifically, I had a paper accepted at the conference but unfortunately, my collaborators at an industry company were unable to fund me to go present the paper. Thanks to NSF's funding, the cost of my trip was significantly more manageable as a graduate student. The experience at the conference was beneficial to me for two main reasons; (1) I was able to meet many researchers there for the first time, and (2) discuss my work and others work to begin meaningful collaborations (e.g., one attendee, there was quite interested in the work I presented and our collaborations since the conference has resulted in a paper submission to a recent conference). Lastly, from the conference, I also learned the importance of socializing with others. I had the benefit of meeting new people to learn about their work and for others there to learn about mine. These interactions led to collaborations and better awareness of the work that I am doing."

 


Last Modified: 10/03/2022
Modified by: James A Clause
